sen.j: 生身天満宮（いくみてんまんぐう）は、京都府南丹市園部町にある神社である。
sen.e: Ikumi-tenmangu Shrine is a shrine in Sonobe-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture
Ikumi-tenmangu Shrine is a shrine in Sonobe-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture
Ikumi-tenmangu Shrine is a shrine in Sonobe-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture
Its old shrine ranking is prefectural shrine.
Its ranked as a prefectural shrine.
Its ranked as a prefectural shrine.
It enshrines SUGAWARA no Michizane.
It enshrines SUGAWARA no Michizane.
It enshrines Sugawara no Michizane.

sen.j: 社伝では道真の存命中の創建と伝えており、これをもって「日本最古の天満宮」と称している。
sen.e: According to the historical document of the shrine, it was built when Michizane was alive, and thus, calls it the 'oldest Tenmangu shrine in Japan.'
According to the historical document on this shrine, it was built when Michizane was alive, and thus, it's called the 'oldest Tenmangu shrine in Japan.'
According to the historical document on this shrine, it was built when Michizane was alive, and thus, it's called the 'oldest Tenmangu shrine in Japan.'
History
History
History

sen.j: 園部の地は菅原氏の知行所であった。
sen.e: Sonobe district was a fiefdom of the Sugawara clan.
The Sonobe district was a fiefdom belonging to the Sugawara clan.
The Sonobe district was a fiefdom belonging to the Sugawara clan.

sen.j: 延喜元年（901年）に道真が大宰府に流された時、園部の代官・武部源蔵は道真の八男・慶能君の養育を頼まれ、小麦山にあった邸内にに小祠を作り、密かに道真の像を安置して生祠として奉斎したのが当社の始まりとする。
sen.e: In 901, when Michizane was exiled to Dazaifu (governmental office in Chikuzen Province), Genzo TAKEBE, the prefectural governor of Sonobe, who was asked to bring up Michizane's eighth son, Keno gimi, built a small shrine in his premises in Komugiyama to secretly enshrine an image of Michizane as seishi (enshrining of a living person), and this is considered to be the origin of this shrine.

In 901, when Michizane was exiled to Dazaifu (the governmental office in Chikuzen Province), Genzo TAKEBE, the prefectural governor of Sonobe, who was asked to bring up Michizane's eighth son, Keno gimi, built a small shrine on his premises in Komugiyama to secretly enshrine an image of Michizane as seishi the enshrining of a living person), and this is considered to be the origin of this shrine.

In 901, when Michizane was exiled to Dazaifu (the governmental office in Chikuzen Province), Genzo TAKEBE, the prefectural governor of Sonobe, who was asked to bring up Michizane's eighth son, Keno gimi, built a small shrine on his premises in Komugiyama to secretly enshrine an image of Michizane as seishi (the enshrining of a living person), and this is considered to be the origin of this shrine.
sen.cmt: 括弧の始まりが脱落。”Michizane as seishi the enshrining of”→”Michizane as seishi (the enshrining of”

sen.j: 延喜3年（903年）に大宰府で道真が亡くなると生祠を霊廟に改め、天暦9年（956年）、改めて神社として祭祀を行った。
sen.e: In 903, when Michizane died in Dazaifu, the seishi was changed to mausoleum, and in 956, newly performed religious services as a shrine.
In 903, when Michizane died in Dazaifu, the seishi was changed to a mausoleum, and in 956, newly performed religious services were performed at the shrine.
In 903, when Michizane died in Dazaifu, the seishi was changed to a mausoleum, and in 956, newly performed religious services were performed at the shrine.

sen.j: 宮司家は武部源蔵の子孫である。
sen.e: The Guji family are descendants of Genzo TAKEBE.
The Guji family are descendants of Genzo TAKEBE.
The Guji family are descendants of Genzo TAKEBE.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には、当地を治めた丹波守護職・細川家や織田家管領が、境内に乱暴狼藉や伐採を禁止する禁制高札を立て、兵乱から守った。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), the guardians of Tanba, the Hosokawa family, and the Oda family control, who governed the region set up kinsei kosatsu (bulletin board for prohibitions) in the premises to prohibit rampageous behavior and lumbering, to prevent disturbance.

In the Sengoku period (the period of warring states), the guardians of Tanba, the Hosokawa family, and the Oda family, who controlled who governed the region, set up kinsei kosatsu (bulletin board of prohibitions) on the premises to prohibit rampageous behavior and loitering, to prevent disturbance.

In the Sengoku period (the period of warring states), the guardians of Tanba, the Hosokawa family, and the Oda family, who controlled who governed the region, set up a kinsei kosatsu (bulletin board of prohibitions) on the grounds of the shrine in order to prevent disturbances; among other things, it prohibited disorderly behavior and loitering.
sen.cmt: 自然な英文に訳し直しました。

sen.j: その高札は現存し、京都府指定文化財となっている。
sen.e: The bulletin board remains today, and is a designated cultural property of Kyoto Prefecture.
The bulletin board remains today, and is a designated cultural property of Kyoto Prefecture.
The bulletin board remains today, and is a designated cultural property of Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 承応2年（1653年）、園部藩初代藩主・小出吉親が小麦山に築城する際に現在地に遷座された。
sen.e: It was relocated to its current location in 1653, when Yoshichika KOIDE, the first feudal lord of Sonobe Domain, built a castle in Komugiyama.
It was relocated to its current location in 1653, when Yoshichika KOIDE, the first feudal lord of the Sonobe Domain, built a castle in Komugiyama.
It was relocated to its current position in 1653, when Yoshichika KOIDE, the first feudal lord of the Sonobe Domain, built a castle in Komugiyama.
sen.cmt: 語句の重複が美しくない。 “ relocated to its current location ” => “ relocated to its current position ”
